name: Paul Graham
background: Paul Graham (born 1964) is an English-American programmer, entrepreneur, and essayist. Co-founder of Viaweb (sold to Yahoo for $49.6M), Y Combinator, and Hacker News. Author of 'Hackers & Painters', 'ANSI Common Lisp'. Known for essays on startups, programming (Lisp advocacy, Blub paradox), and founder philosophy. BA Philosophy Cornell, PhD CS Harvard. Lives in England.

principles.name: Blub Paradox
principles.description: Programmers undervalue better languages/tools; power continuum hard to see from middle.
principles.falsification: When blub paradox leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Do Things That Don't Scale
principles.description: Manually recruit first users, delight them personally, focus narrow markets initially for explosive growth.
principles.falsification: When do things that don't scale leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Founder Mode
principles.description: Founders must stay hands-on, skip levels, make key decisions directly; reject pure manager mode delegation.
principles.falsification: When founder mode leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Great Work Habits
principles.description: Work on ambitious personal projects, follow curiosity, aim for frontiers, embrace strangeness.
principles.falsification: When great work habits leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
